nodes.content:
{\rm a)} The map $Q\mapsto [Q]_\alpha$
is constant on double cosets $S_n\cdot g\cdot S_n$
and is an injective map 
\begin{equation}
S_n\backslash S_{\alpha+n}/S_n\to \Pi_\alpha.
\end{equation}

\sm

{\rm b)} If $n\ge \alpha$, when this map is a bijection.
If $n<\alpha$, then the image consists of elements
of $\Pi_\alpha$ of rank $\ge\alpha-n$.
nodes.content_preview: a) The map Q [Q]_ is constant on double cosets S_n g S_n and is an injective map S_n S_+n/S_n _. b) If n , when this map is a bijection.

nodes.content:
\label{pr:isomorphic}
For fixed $\alpha$ and
 $n\ge\alpha$ all algebras $\C[S_n\backslash S_{\alpha+n}/S_n]$
 are\footnote{Noncanonically.} isomorphic.
nodes.content_preview: For fixed and n all algebras are isomorphic.
nodes.label: pr:isomorphic

nodes.content:
\label{th:homomorphism}
{\rm a)} $\dim  \bbO[\alpha,\nu]=\#\Pi_\alpha$.

\sm 

{\rm b)} Let $n\ge 0$ be integer. 
Assign for any $g\in S_\alpha$ the element
$$
 a(g):=
\frac1{n!}\sum_{\sigma\in S_n}\delta_{g\times \sigma}
\in \C[S_n\backslash S_{\alpha+n}/S_n].
$$ 
 For any $i\le \alpha$ denote
 $$
 \theta_i:=\frac{1}{n!}\sum_{h\in K(i(\alpha+1))K}
 \delta_h\in \C[S_n\backslash S_{\alpha+n}/S_n].
 $$
 Then the map
 $$
 \Theta_i\mapsto \theta_i, \qquad A(g)\mapsto a(g) 
 $$
 determines a homomorphism $\bbO[\alpha;n]\to \C[S_n\backslash S_{\alpha+n}/S_n]$.
 
 \sm
 
 {\rm c)} If $n\ge \alpha$, then this homomorphism is an isomorphism.
 If $0\le n<\alpha$, then it is surjective.
 
\sm  
 
 {\rm d)} For all $\nu\in \C$ except finite collection
 of values, the algebras $\bbO[\alpha;\nu]$ are
 \footnote{Noncanonically.}  isomorphic
 (and are direct sums of matrix algebras).
nodes.content_preview: a) =#_. b) Let n 0 be integer. Assign for any g S_ the element a(g):= 1n!_ S_n_g . For any i denote _i:=_h K(i(+1))K _h .
nodes.label: th:homomorphism

nodes.content:
\label{l:A-1}
Let $h\in S_\alpha$ be a permutation supported by the set
$\{i_1,\dots,i_k\}$, where all $i_m$ are distinct. Then
$$\deg_\Theta\Bigl(\bigl((A(h)-A(1)\bigr)\,
\Theta_{i_1}\dots \Theta_{i_k}\Bigr)<k.$$
nodes.content_preview: Let h S_ be a permutation supported by the set i_1,,i_k, where all i_m are distinct. Then _(((A(h)-A(1)), _i_1 _i_k)<k.
nodes.label: l:A-1

nodes.label: th:basis

nodes.content:
\label{pr:positivity}
For sufficiently large $\nu\in \R$ this form is positive definite.
nodes.content_preview: For sufficiently large this form is positive definite.
nodes.label: pr:positivity

nodes.content:
The limit algebra $\bbO[\alpha]$ is the semigroup
algebra $\C[\Pi_\alpha]$.
nodes.content_preview: The limit algebra is the semigroup algebra .

nodes.content:
\label{pr:limit}
The algebra $\bbO[\alpha]$ is
\footnote{Noncanonically.} isomorphic to the algebras
$\bbO[\alpha;n]$ for $n\ge \alpha$.
nodes.content_preview: The algebra is isomorphic to the algebras for n .
nodes.label: pr:limit

nodes.content:
Denote by $\frt(i_1,\dots,i_k)$ the double
coset $S_nT_{i_1,\dots,i_k}S_n$. Then 
$$\iota(\delta_{\frt(i_1,\dots,i_k)})=n(n-1)\dots(n-r+1).$$
nodes.content_preview: Denote by (i_1,,i_k) the double coset S_nT_i_1,,i_kS_n. Then (_(i_1,,i_k))=n(n-1)(n-r+1).

nodes.content:
The collection of dimensions of nontrivial spaces of 
$S_n$-fixed vectors in irreducible representations of
$S_{n+\alpha}$ is
\begin{equation}
\Bigl\{ \frac{\alpha!}{t!\,(\alpha-t)!}\,
 \dim\rho(\alpha-t;\lambda')
\Bigr\}, 
\label{eq:multi}
\end{equation}
where $t$ ranges in the set $\{0,1,\dots,\alpha\}$
and $\lambda'$ ranges in the set of Young diagrams of size
 $\alpha-t$.
nodes.content_preview: The collection of dimensions of nontrivial spaces of S_n-fixed vectors in irreducible representations of S_n+ is , (-t;') , where t ranges in the set...
nodes.label: eq:multi

nodes.content:
For each $m$ the linear subspace $\bbO[\alpha;\nu]_m$
is generated by elements \eqref{eq:basis} with  $k\le m$.

nodes.content:
For each $r\ge 0$ the image of $\bbO[\alpha; n]_r$
 consists of all elements of $\C[S_n\backslash S_{\alpha+n}/S_n]$
supported by the set of all $Q\in S_{\alpha+n}$
 such that $\rk [Q]_\alpha\ge\alpha-r$.

nodes.content:
\label{cor:dim-ravno}
If integer $n$ is $\ge \alpha$, then $\dim \bbO[\alpha;n]= \#\Pi_\alpha$.
So, elements \eqref{eq:basis} form a basis in
$\bbO[\alpha;n]$
